videos.title: Gemini 3 Deep Think: AI With 3,455 Elo Rating Destroys Math Olympics (Better Than Humans)
videos.creator: AI Perspectives
videos.description: Gemini 3 Deep Think just changed everything we thought AI could do. Google's latest AI reasoning model solved 18 previously unsolved research problems, caught mistakes in peer-reviewed papers, and achieved gold medal performance across multiple scientific olympiads. In this video, I break down exactly what makes Deep Think different from OpenAI's o1 and why researchers are calling this a game-changer.
videos.detailed_summary: This video provides comprehensive analysis of Google DeepMind's Gemini 3 Deep Think, a breakthrough AI reasoning model that represents a major advancement in artificial intelligence capabilities. The model achieved unprecedented performance across multiple scientific benchmarks, including a record-breaking 48.4% on Humanity's Last Exam, 84.6% on ARC-AGI-2 (an unprecedented achievement), and an impressive 3,455 Elo rating on Codeforces, placing it at Legendary Grandmaster level. Deep Think earned gold medals across multiple international olympiads including Mathematics, Physics, and Chemistry competitions in 2025, demonstrating superhuman performance in complex scientific reasoning. The model is built around System 2 thinking architecture, which enables deeper reasoning and extended computation time compared to traditional fast-response AI systems. Real-world applications are already emerging: at Rutgers University, professor Lisa Carbone used Deep Think to detect errors in peer-reviewed mathematical research papers. At Duke University's Wang Lab, the model contributed to semiconductor crystal growth research breakthroughs. The model successfully solved a 10-year-old mathematical conjecture and tackled 18 previously unsolved research-level problems across multiple scientific domains. The video extensively compares Deep Think against competitors including OpenAI's o1 and o1 Pro models, Anthropic's Claude Sonnet, and GPT-4.5 Pro, positioning Deep Think as superior for scientific and mathematical reasoning tasks. Google has made the model accessible through the AI Ultra subscription tier in the Gemini App, and researchers and enterprises can apply for early API access through a dedicated application form. The presenter discusses the Aletheia Agent for mathematical research and references multiple official resources from Google's blog and DeepMind's research publications. The video emphasizes that Deep Think is specifically designed for scientists, engineers, and researchers working on complex technical problems requiring extended reasoning capabilities.
chapters: 00:00 - Shocking Hook: AI Catches Harvard Mistakes
00:36 - What You'll Learn in This Video
04:07 - Deep Think vs OpenAI o1 vs Claude
04:37 - What This Means for the Future
05:10 - How to Access Deep Think Now

references.claim_or_topic: Google DeepMind Gemini 3 Deep Think model announcement and capabilities

primary_source.title: Gemini 3 Deep Think is now available

accessibility.notes: Official Google blog post freely accessible

citation.apa: Doshi, T. (2025, December 4). Gemini 3 Deep Think is now available. Google Blog.
citation.bibtex: @misc{doshi2025gemini3deepthink, title={Gemini 3 Deep Think is now available}, author={Doshi, Tulsee}, year={2025}, url={https://blog.google/products-and-platforms/products/gemini/gemini-3-deep-think/}}

source_verification.summary_of_source: The Google blog post announces Gemini 3 Deep Think as available for AI Ultra subscribers, highlighting its advanced reasoning for math, science, and logic. It reports 41.0% on HLE without tools and 45.1% on ARC-AGI-2 with code execution. A subsequent Feb 12, 2026 update post reports further upgraded scores.
source_verification.discrepancies: The original Dec 2025 post reports 41.0% HLE and 45.1% ARC-AGI-2, while the video claims 48.4% HLE and 84.6% ARC-AGI-2. The higher numbers likely come from the Feb 2026 upgrade announcement.
source_verification.confidence_reason: The original blog post scores differ from the video's claimed scores; the Feb 2026 update likely contains the updated benchmarks but the exact URL for the update post could not be fully verified.

references.claim_or_topic: Gemini 3 Deep Think Feb 2026 major upgrade with updated benchmark scores

primary_source.title: Gemini 3 Deep Think: Advancing science, research and engineering

accessibility.notes: The exact URL for the Feb 12 update post returned 404 when tested; the post exists per Google search results but the precise slug could not be confirmed.

citation.apa: Google DeepMind. (2026, February 12). Gemini 3 Deep Think: Advancing science, research and engineering. Google Blog.
citation.bibtex: @misc{googledeepmind2026deepthinkupdate, title={Gemini 3 Deep Think: Advancing science, research and engineering}, author={{Google DeepMind}}, year={2026}, url={https://blog.google/technology/google-deepmind/gemini-3-deep-think-update/}}

source_verification.summary_of_source: Per Google search results and blog listing, the Feb 12 2026 update post describes a major upgrade to Gemini 3 Deep Think mode for scientific reasoning, research, and engineering tasks. This update likely contains the improved benchmark scores cited in the video.
source_verification.discrepancies: Could not fully verify the exact benchmark numbers (48.4% HLE, 84.6% ARC-AGI-2) as the direct URL was not accessible.
source_verification.confidence_reason: The post is confirmed to exist via Google search results and blog listings but direct URL could not be verified.

references.claim_or_topic: Humanity's Last Exam benchmark for AI evaluation

accessibility.notes: Open access preprint on arXiv; also hosted at lastexam.ai

citation.apa: Phan, L., Gatti, A., Han, Z., Li, N., Hu, J., Zhang, H., ... & Hendrycks, D. (2025). Humanity's Last Exam. arXiv preprint arXiv:2501.14249.
citation.bibtex: @article{phan2025humanitylastexam, title={Humanity's Last Exam}, author={Phan, Long and Gatti, Alice and Han, Ziwen and Li, Nathaniel and Hu, Josephina and Zhang, Hugh and others}, journal={arXiv preprint arXiv:2501.14249}, year={2025}}

source_verification.summary_of_source: Humanity's Last Exam is a multi-discipline benchmark created by Scale AI SEAL, featuring extremely challenging questions designed to test frontier AI model capabilities at the expert level across many academic fields. It was designed to be a benchmark that would be very difficult for current AI models.
source_verification.discrepancies: None significant. The video correctly references HLE as a major benchmark for AI evaluation.
source_verification.confidence_reason: The arXiv paper is publicly available and is a well-known benchmark in the AI community.

accessibility.notes: Public benchmark leaderboard and task set

citation.apa: ARC Prize Foundation. (2025). ARC-AGI-2. ARC Prize. https://arcprize.org/arc-agi/2/
citation.bibtex: @misc{arcprize2025arcagi2, title={ARC-AGI-2}, author={{ARC Prize Foundation}}, year={2025}, url={https://arcprize.org/arc-agi/2/}}

source_verification.summary_of_source: ARC-AGI-2 is the second iteration of the Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus benchmark designed to test general intelligence capabilities in AI systems, requiring novel reasoning rather than pattern matching from training data.
source_verification.discrepancies: The video claims 84.6% on ARC-AGI-2 which would be an extraordinary score; the original Dec 2025 blog post reported 45.1%. The 84.6% figure may come from the Feb 2026 update.
source_verification.confidence_reason: The benchmark exists and is verifiable, but the specific score of 84.6% could not be independently confirmed from the sources checked.

citation.apa: Codeforces. (n.d.). Codeforces competitive programming platform. https://codeforces.com/

source_verification.summary_of_source: Codeforces is a competitive programming platform with an Elo-based rating system. Legendary Grandmaster is the highest rank, typically requiring ratings above 3000. A 3,455 rating would place the model among the very top performers.
source_verification.discrepancies: Could not independently verify the exact 3,455 Elo rating claim from Codeforces directly, but the ranking system description is accurate.
source_verification.confidence_reason: Codeforces rating system is well-documented, but the specific AI model rating was not independently verified on the platform.

videos.title: AI News Feb 15 |AI Agents Open Real PRs, LLM=CPU, Meta Afterlife Patent, HK Robotaxi |
videos.creator: nullmicgo
videos.description: February 15, 2026 – AI news roundup: AI agents now open real pull requests in major open-source projects (Socket.dev); Agent Hypervisor – reality virtualization for AI agents to block prompt injection & ZombieAgent (sv-pro); AI Station Navigator – LLM=CPU, Agents=Processes, Skills=Apps (canishowtime); cgrep – local, code-aware search for AI coding agents, 95% token reduction (meghendra6); Meta patents AI to post on behalf of deceased users (Business Insider); Mathematicians launch First Proof – math exam for AI (Scientific American); Oxford study: AI medical chatbots no better than search (Unwire); Hong Kong plans commercial robotaxi without backup driver (Unwire); Waymo pays gig workers ~$11 to close car doors (Unwire); OpenAI Python SDK v2.21.0 adds container network_policy & skills.
videos.detailed_summary: This comprehensive AI news roundup covers multiple significant developments across the artificial intelligence industry on February 15, 2026. A major development is AI agents now autonomously opening real pull requests in major open-source projects, as reported by Socket.dev, marking a new era of AI participation in collaborative software development. The Agent Hypervisor project (by sv-pro on GitHub) introduces reality virtualization technology specifically designed for AI agents to block prompt injection attacks and introduces ZombieAgent capabilities for enhanced security. The AI Station Navigator project (by canishowtime) presents a revolutionary conceptual framework comparing LLMs to CPUs, AI agents to processes, and skills to applications, offering a new mental model for understanding AI system architecture. The cgrep tool (by meghendra6) provides local, code-aware search functionality optimized for AI coding agents with an impressive 95% token reduction, significantly improving efficiency for AI-assisted development. Meta has filed a controversial patent for AI technology that would enable posting on behalf of deceased users, raising significant ethical questions about digital afterlife and consent, as reported by Business Insider. Mathematicians have launched First Proof, a specialized mathematical examination designed specifically to test AI capabilities, as covered by Scientific American, representing the mathematics community's effort to create standardized AI benchmarks. An Oxford University study reveals that AI medical chatbots perform no better than traditional web search for medical information, challenging assumptions about AI's near-term utility in healthcare, per Unwire.hk reporting. Hong Kong announced plans for commercial robotaxi services operating without backup human drivers, representing a significant regulatory advancement for autonomous vehicle deployment in Asia. Waymo is paying gig workers approximately $11 per task to close car doors and perform minor vehicle maintenance tasks, highlighting the human labor still required to support autonomous vehicle fleets. OpenAI released Python SDK version 2.21.0 with new features including container network_policy configurations and skills framework, advancing the tooling available for developers building AI applications.

source_verification.discrepancies: None significant. The repo description matches the video's characterization of the LLM=CPU analogy.

processing_notes: Sourced 17 total references across 2 videos (7 from video 1, 10 from video 2)
14 of 17 sources confirmed accessible; 3 had URL issues (primarily the Google DeepMind update blog post slug)
Video 1 benchmark claims (48.4% HLE, 84.6% ARC-AGI-2) differ from the original Dec 2025 announcement (41.0% HLE, 45.1% ARC-AGI-2); these likely reflect the Feb 2026 update
All GitHub repositories referenced in video 2 (sv-pro/agent-hypervisor, canishowtime/ai-station-navigator, meghendra6/cgrep) were confirmed to exist and be publicly accessible
The Waymo gig workers story was widely covered by CNBC, Mashable, Fast Company, and Business Insider confirming the ~$11.25 per task claim
Some claims from video 1 (Rutgers/Lisa Carbone, Duke Wang Lab) appear to originate solely from Google promotional materials with no independent verification found
The Oxford AI chatbots study was confirmed via the official ox.ac.uk press release
